Reactive adsorption of CO from low CO concentrations streams on the surface of Pd/CeO2 catalysts Georgios Bampos a Panagiota Bika a Paraskevi Panagiotopoulou b ⁎ Xenophon E. Verykios a ⁎ a Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, GR-26504, Patras, Greece Department of Chemical Engineering University of Patras Patras GR-26504 Greece Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Patras, GR-26504 Patras, Greece b School of Environmental Engineering, Technical University of Crete, GR-73100, Chania, Greece School of Environmental Engineering Technical University of Crete Chania GR-73100 Greece School of Environmental Engineering, Technical University of Crete, GR-73100 Chania, Greece ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Reformate gas mixtures introduced into PEM fuel cells may contain traces of CO which can irreversibly poison electrocatalysts. A means to eliminate such traces of CO from reformate mixtures via reactive adsorption onto solid catalysts is described. The reactive adsorption/desorption characteristics of CO were investigated over Pd/CeO2 catalysts with respect of Pd loading and adsorption temperature employing in situ FTIR and transient MS techniques. Results showed that CO adsorption is enhanced with increasing Pd content or decreasing adsorption temperature. Production of CO2 during CO-TPD occurs in a bifuntional manner with the participation of both the metallic phase and the support. Although the adsorption of CO is limited upon interaction of 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalyst with a reformate mixture, results demonstrate that elimination of residual CO, present in the exit of methanation (or oxidation) reactor, is feasible via successive cycles of CO adsorption and oxidation at 40 °C. Keywords MS DRIFTS CO elimination CO adsorption CO-TPD Pd/CeO2 catalysts 1 Introduction The interest for hydrogen production, combined with fuel cell systems, has received much attention during the last decades due to its environment-friendly and renewable usage as a clean energy carrier for the production of electricity [1–6]. Hydrogen can be produced from fossil fuels with the use of several methods, including natural gas steam reforming and coal gasification or from renewable resources, using methods such as water electrolysis and biomass pyrolysis, gasification or steam reforming [1,4,6]. A fuel processor designed for use with polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cells should be able to convert fuel into a hydrogen-rich gas stream free of CO [7]. Removal of CO from H2 stream is a key aspect in the efficient implementation of the proposed technology. CO reduction can be achieved via treatment of the reformate gas in a water-gas shift (WGS) unit, which decreases CO concentration to 0.5–1.0 %, followed by an additional cleanup step in order to reduce residual CO, which may involve preferential oxidation or methanation of CO [7–10]. However, in certain cases, CO concentration cannot be reduced below the levels (<50 ppm) dictated by the poisoning limit of the Pt electrodes. Therefore, alternative technologies should be developed, which could be used as final purification step after the CO methanation or oxidation reaction. One strategy that has been proposed is the use of selective membranes for CO removal, which, however, suffers from the high cost of such perm-selectivity membranes [6,11]. An alternative approach for the removal of residual CO is the use of a catalytic material able to adsorb CO. The catalyst will be subjected to successive cycles of (a) interaction with the reformate mixture in order to adsorb residual CO and, possibly converted to CO2 under unaerobic conditions, and (b) oxidation so as to oxidize remaining adsorbed CO toward CO2 under aerobic conditions. Consequently, it is important to develop catalysts characterized by high CO adsorption/reaction capacity at sufficiently low temperatures, able to retard H2 oxidation reaction and capable of retaining its physicochemical properties after repeated adsorption/oxidation cycles. A prerequisite to accomplish this task is to investigate the reactive adsorption/desorption characteristics of CO and to identify the physicochemical parameters and operating conditions for the efficient removal of residual CO (< 50 ppm) met in the outlet of CO methanation or oxidation reactor in fuel processors. The investigation of the interaction of carbon monoxide with metal surfaces has been of great interest for several decades, since CO chemisorption is the elementary step of the mechanistic pathway of several catalytic processes, such as CO methanation [12], water-gas shift [13], Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [14], alcohols formation [15,16] and CO oxidation [17] reactions. However, most of the studies reported so far use concentrations of CO higher than 0.5%, which is significantly higher than that exiting the CO methantion or oxidation reactor in fuel processors. Thus, in the present study the reactive chemisorption of CO from low CO concentrations (0.004%) streams on the surface of Pd/CeO2 catalysts is investigated, with respect of adsorption temperature (40–90 °C) and palladium loading (0–1 wt.%). The aim is to identify the nature of active sites for CO reactive adsorption and to optimize operating adsorption conditions for complete removal of CO. The adsorption/desorption characteristics of CO are also investigated using a reformate mixture, containing also H2, CO2 and H2O, which may influence the proposed process. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization Catalysts were prepared by the wet impregnation method [18] with the use of PdCl2 (Alfa) as metal precursor salt and a commercial cerium oxide powder (Alfa products) as support. All samples were reduced under H2 flow at 300 °C for 2 h. The nominal metal loading of catalysts thus prepared varied in the range of 0.25–1 wt.%. Carrier and catalysts were characterized with respect to their specific surface area, exposed metallic surface area and mean crystallite size employing nitrogen physisorption at liquid nitrogen temperature and selective chemisorption of CO at 25 °C. The structural characteristics of selected catalysts were also investigated by Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) following standard procedures [19]. Details on the equipment and procedures used for catalyst characterization can be found elsewhere [18]. 2.2 Transient mass spectrometry and temperature-programmed desorption studies Transient-MS and temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments were carried out using an Omnistar/Pfeiffer Vacuum mass spectrometer (MS) for on-line monitoring of effluent gas composition. The apparatus and procedures used have been described in detail elsewhere [12]. Briefly, an amount of 150 mg of catalyst was placed in a quartz microreactor and heated at 450 °C under He flow for 15 min, in order to remove adsorbed species from the catalyst surface, and subsequently cooled to the selected temperature (25, 40, 70 or 90 °C). The catalyst was then oxidized in situ at 25, 40, 70 or 90 °C for 30 min under flowing 20%O2/He. The sample was then heated at 500 °C under He flow for 15 min in order to remove adsorbed species from the catalyst surface and subsequently cooled to the selected temperature (25, 40, 70 or 90 °C). Transient experiments were then carried out by switching the flow to a mixture consisting of 0.004%CO (in He) with the use of a chromatographic valve equipped with an electronic actuator. The feed also contained a small amount of an inert gas (0.01%Ar), the response curve of which represents the flow pattern and the residence time distribution of gaseous reactants flowing through the reactor and the transportation lines. When adsorption of CO is completed the flow was switched to He for 10 min, followed by linear heating (β = 15 °C min−1) up to 700 °C. Immediately after the Temperature-Programmed Desorption (TPD) experiment, the catalyst was cooled to room temperature under He flow and the feed composition was switched to 20%O2 (in He). After 10 min of exposure at room temperature, the catalyst was heated linearly (β = 15 °C /min) up to 700 °C under 20%O2/He flow (Temperature-Programmed Oxidation, TPO). In all experiments, the total flow rate through the reactor was 30 cm3 min−1. Responses of the mass spectrometer were calibrated against standard mixtures of accurately known composition. When necessary (e.g. CO2−CO signals), the cracking coefficient determined in separate experiments was also taken into account in the calculations of gas effluent concentrations. Similar experiments were conducted using a feed composition consisting of 0.0038%CO, 0.044%Ar, 0.29%CO2, 6.8%H2 and 3.1% H2O (in He). Steam addition occurred by controlling the flow of a He line, which passed through a saturator containing water, and then mixed with the gas stream coming from a gas cylinder of accurately known composition (7% H2, 0.3% CO2, 0.046% Ar, 0.004% CO). The concentration of H2O at the exit of the saturator was estimated by the vapor pressure of water at room temperature. The stability of the reformate gas mixture was checked during calibration where the gas mixture was introduced to a by-pass loop stream for more than 3.5 h. In these experiments the catalyst was heated at 450 °C under He flow for 15 min followed by cooling to 40 °C, where it was oxidized in situ for 30 min under flowing 20%O2/He. The flow was then switched to the above reformate gas mixture for 50 min followed by switch to He for 2 min and subsequent oxidation for 50 min under flowing 20%O2/He, in order to oxidize CO and remove adsorbed species from the catalyst surface. The flow was then switched to He for 2 min and the same experimental procedure was repeated at 40 °C (0.0038%CO + 0.044%Ar+0.29%CO2+6.8%H2+3.1% H2O/He (50 min) → oxidation (50 min) → He (2 min)). When both adsorption/desorption cycles are completed the catalyst was cooled to room temperature in He flow for 10 min, followed by linear heating (β = 15 °C min−1) at 500 °C. All gases (He, 0.004%CO-0.01%Ar/He, 7%H2-0.3%CO2-0.046%Ar-0.004%CO/He, 20%O2) used are supplied from high-pressure gas cylinders and are of ultra-high purity. It should be noted that each experiment was repeated at least three times and results presented below are highly reproducible. Based on transient MS, TPD and TPO experiments the amounts (μmol g−1) of CO, CO2, H2 or H2O adsorbed/produced during CO adsorption, TPD and TPO experiments were calculated. In all cases, the relative experimental error of the estimated amounts was lower than 0.5%. 2.3 In situ FTIR spectroscopy The interaction of CO with the catalyst surface was investigated employing in situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy. Experiments were carried out using a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer equipped with a diffuse reflectance (DRIFT) cell (Spectra Tech), an MCT detector and a KBr beam splitter. FTIR spectra were collected with a 64-scan data acquisition at a resolution of 4 cm−1 in a controlled gas atmosphere and temperature. In a typical experiment, the catalyst powder was heated at 450 °C under He flow for 10 min and then oxidized in flowing oxygen (20%O2 in He) at 25 or 70 °C for 30 min. The cell was then flushed with He at 450 °C for 10 min and subsequently cooled to 25 or 70 °C under He flow for 10 min. In the cooling stage, background spectra were collected at temperatures of interest. The flow was then switched to a gas mixture consisting of 0.004%CO + 0.01%Ar (in He) and spectra were obtained at the selected temperature as functions of time-on-stream. After 210 min on stream, the system was purged with He for 10 min and temperature was stepwise increased under He flow up to 450 °C. Spectra were recorded 3 min after reaching the desired temperature. In all experiments, the total flow rate through the DRIFT cell was 30 cm3 min−1. All gases (He, 0.004%CO-0.01%Ar/He, 20%O2) used are supplied from high-pressure gas cylinders and are of ultra-high purity. Possible variations of the obtained spectra upon prolonged exposure of catalysts in He flow were checked and no change was observed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Results of catalyst characterization are summarized in Table 1 , where specific surface areas (SSA) of both CeO2 carrier and Pd/CeO2 catalysts along with Pd loading, dispersion and mean crystallite size (d Pd) are listed for all samples investigated. It is observed that the SSA of commercial CeO2 support used in the present study was found to be 47 m2/g, and was not altered significantly upon addition of Pd. Palladium dispersion, as determined by CO chemisorptions at room temperature, decreases from 99 to 83.5% with increasing Pd loading from 0.25 to 1.0 wt.%, respectively, whereas Pd mean crystallite size increases from 0.8 to 1.4 nm. The morphology of catalysts was further investigated using transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Representative HR-TEM images obtained from CeO2, 0.25%Pd/CeO2 and 1%Pd/CeO2 samples are presented in Fig. 1 , where it is observed that all samples comprise fairly homogeneous spherical CeO2 particles of approximately 10 nm diameter. The d-spacing was measured for all the investigated samples and results showed the presence of the (111) (dspacing = 0.32 nm), (200) (dspacing = 0.28 nm), (220) (dspacing = 0.19 nm) and (311) (dspacing = 0.16 nm) crystallographic planes of CeO2 (JCPDS Card No. 2-1306). In the case of 0.25%Pd/CeO2 and 1%Pd/CeO2 catalysts, Pd particles are hard to be discerned, most probably due to their small size. This is supported by CO chemisorption results, which indicated that the mean Pd particle size for 0.25%Pd/CeO2 and 1%Pd/CeO2 catalysts is 0.8 and 1.4 nm, respectively (Table 1). 3.2 Effect of adsorption temperature on the reactive adsorption/desorption characteristics of CO over 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalysts 3.2.1 Transient MS results The adsorption of CO on the surface of 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalyst was investigated by transient mass spectrometry at selected temperatures in the range of 25 to 90 °C and results obtained are presented in Fig. 2 A-D. For each experiment, the response curves of CO, CO2 and Ar were recorded as functions of time-on-stream after the switch, He → 0.004%CO + 0.01%Ar (in He) over the pre-oxidized sample (at the temperature of the adsorption experiment). It should be noted that Ar signal has been normalized with that of CO in order to present the expected equivalent response in case that CO is not adsorbed/reacted in the reactor system. It is observed that, at 25 °C (Fig. 2A) the carbon monoxide response starts to increase after 160 min on stream, whereas time longer than 210 min is required to reach the input steady state value. The response of CO2 remains unaffected with time on stream, indicating that CO conversion to CO2 is not feasible under the present experimental conditions. It should be noted that the spikes observed in the signals of CO and Ar in the first 3 min of the transient experiments is due to incorrect balance of the pressures in the two gas streams at the switching chromatographic valve. The amount of CO adsorbed on the surface of 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalyst for 210 min on stream was estimated from this experiment (by subtracting the area below the CO response curve from that of Ar) to be 63.3 μmol g−1 (Table 2 ). Increase of adsorption temperature from 25 to 90 °C (Fig. 2, A–D) results in a progressive decrease of the response time of CO from 210 to 30 min, which is accompanied by a decrease of the amount of CO adsorbed from 63.3 to 14.7 μmol g−1, respectively (Table 2). Small amounts of CO2 are also detected for adsorption temperatures higher than 40 °C, indicating that conversion of CO toward CO2 is enhanced with increasing temperature of CO interaction with the catalyst surface. In Fig. 2E-H are shown the corresponding TPD patterns obtained following exposure of the pre-oxidized 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalyst to 0.004%CO-0.01%Ar (in He) mixture at temperatures (T ad) of 25, 40, 70 or 90 °C. The responses of CO, CO2 and H2 are plotted as functions of desorption temperature. It is observed that when adsorption takes place at T ad=25 °C CO desorbs exhibiting two maxima, a broad one located at ca 230 °C and a sharp one at 392 °C. According to previous studies, CO desorption at different temperatures is associated to distinct CO adsorption species. It has been reported that CO desorption peaks evolved at temperatures lower than 330 °C are due to linear-bonded CO species, whereas those detected at higher temperatures are due to desorption of bridged-bonded CO [20–22]. Desorption of CO is accompanied by evolution of significantly larger amounts of CO2, the profile of which is characterized by a low temperature (LT) peak at ca 176 °C accompanied by a shoulder at ca 220 °C and a medium temperature (MT) peak at ca 376 °C. The MT CO2 peak is accompanied by evolution of H2 in the same temperature range. The amounts (μmol g−1) of CO, CO2 and H2 evolved during TPD experiment are presented in Table 2. The lower amount of CO desorbed during TPD compared to that of CO2 produced indicates that only part of CO desorbs molecularly: (1) CO(Pd) ↔ CO(g) while a larger amount of adsorbed CO is involved in surface reactions, upon heating under He flow, yielding CO2 in the gas phase. Part of the LT CO2 peak can be attributed to reduction of partially oxidized palladium that might be formed on the catalyst surface during catalysts pretreatment (oxidation for 30 min under flowing 20%O2/He) [23]: (2) PdO x + xCO → Pd + xCO2 Another possible route for the production of CO2 at low temperatures is the dissociation of CO (Boudouard reaction) [20,24]: (3) 2 CO → C + C O 2 The occurrence of the latter reaction was verified by conducting TPO experiments immediately after completion of the TPD experiment shown in Fig. 2E. Results obtained are presented in Fig. 3 , where it is observed that the profile of CO2 thus produced exhibits a broad peak with a maximum at 226 °C and two shoulders at around 150 and 300 °C. The amount of carbon deposited on the catalyst surface during TPD of CO was estimated to be between 1.7 and 2.7 μmol g−1 (Table 2), indicating that the Boudouard reaction is operable under the experimental conditions of Fig. 2E. However, the total amount of CO2 produced during TPD (Table 2) is significantly higher, implying that CO dissociation is not the only source of CO2 production, in agreement with previous studies [24]. Regarding the MT CO2 peak, evolution of H2 in the same temperature range indicates that part of CO2 produced may be due to the WGS reaction, which is believed to take place at the metal-support interface via interaction of adsorbed CO species with hydroxyl groups of the support, resulting in the formation of formates followed by their decomposition to CO2 [20,24]: (4) CO(Pd) + 2OH− (CeO2) → CO2(g) + H2(g) + O2- (CeO2) According to the stoichiometry of Eq.4, if the WGS reaction was the only reaction taking place in the temperature range of 300–400 °C, the amount of H2 produced should be equal to that of CO2. This is not the case for the results of Fig. 2E, since CO2 concentration is significantly higher compared to that of H2. This indicates that another reaction is operable yielding CO2 at medium temperatures. It has been proposed that supported Pd catalysts favor CO adsorption on the surface of the support, which in some cases is followed by reverse spillover of CO from the support to the Pd particles or Pd/support interface, where it chemisorbs and may be oxidized [25–28]. It can then be suggested that CO is adsorbed on the surface of CeO2 support leading to the formation of carbonate species, part of which are then decomposed producing CO2 in the gas phase at medium temperatures (Eq. 5). The rest is possibly diffused on the Pd surface, which may then be desorbed (MT CO peak) in the gas phase (Eq.1) or participates in surface reactions (Eq.3,4). (5) CO(CeO2) → Carbonate species → CO2(g) The formation of surface carbonate species, which are then decompose to CO2, has been also proposed to occur via interaction of adsorbed CO species on Pd2+ sites and the lattice oxygen of interfacial CeO2 [29]. It is well known that CeO2 is characterized by high oxygen storage capacity, which has been previously found to increase in the presence of noble metals on its surface and accompanied by an increased oxygen release rate [30–32]. This has been related to the synergistic reduction of CeO2 in close contact with the metal [32] and may influence the spillover effects observed over CeO2-supported noble metal catalysts. Moreover, the formation of carbonate species through the spillover of CO adsorbed on Pd to CeO2 surface cannot be excluded. As mentioned above, the amount of CO adsorbed on the surface of 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalyst for 220 min on stream at 25 °C was found to be 63.3 μmol g−1 (Table 2). The surface coverage of adsorbed CO was calculated by dividing the number of adsorbed CO molecules with the number of gram atoms of Pd on the surface of CeO2 (calculated by CO chemisorption measurement), and was found to be 18 (>1). Similarly, the values of CO surface coverage for adsorption temperatures of 40, 70 and 90 °C were estimated to be higher than 1 and equal to 10.4, 8.8 and 4.2, respectively. These results provide strong evidence that CO is not only adsorbed on the Pd surface, but a significant part is adsorbed on the surface of CeO2 support. As it will be discussed below, indeed, part of CO is adsorbed on CeO2 surface. However, the amount of adsorbed CO was found to be low in order to account for the estimated surface coverage of adsorbed CO. This indicates that, under the present experimental conditions, part of CO migrates from Pd to CeO2 surface resulting in CO surface coverage higher than 1. Another possible route for the conversion of CO toward CO2 is via oxidation of CO adsorbed on Pd by oxygen that was migrated from CeO2 to Pd surface. Oxygen spillover from CeO2 to metal surface was previously observed over Rh/CeO2 [33], Pt/CeO2 [34] and Pd/CeO2 [35] catalysts. Christou et al. [35] found that both the CO oxidation rate and the oxygen spillover from CeO2 to the Pd/PdO surface is enhanced over well dispersed Pd particles. Moreover, Tsuji et al. [36] reported that the higher activity of Pd/Mn2O3 catalyst for CO oxidation compared to that of Pd/Al2O3 or pure Mn2O3 is due to the removal of lattice oxygen of Mn2O3 to Pd surface at low temperatures. Increasing the adsorption temperature of CO from 25 to 90 °C results in a significant decrease of the total amounts of desorbed CO and CO2 produced (Fig. 2E–H, Table 2), which agrees well with the corresponding CO adsorption results presenting in Fig. 2A–D. Rumpf et al. [27] studied the role of the support on the CO oxidation reaction over Pd/Al2O3 catalysts and proposed that CO molecules impinging on the support diffuse across the support surface to the Pd-Al2O3 interface where they are chemisorbed and may be oxidized. The authors demonstrated that the number of CO molecules reaching the interface by surface diffusion decreases with increasing temperature. This may be the case for the results of the present study, since, as suggested above, part of CO2 evolved during TPD is produced with the participation of the CeO2 support. It is of interest to note that when adsorption of CO takes place at 70 and 90 °C a new CO2 peak appears at around 610 °C, the relative intensity of which increases with increasing Tads. This high temperature (HT) CO2 peak has been previously attributed to the Pd-catalyzed reduction of the CeO2 surface [23], according to: (6) CeO2 +xCO → CeO 2-x + xCO2 (x < 2) The overall carbon balance of the TPD experiments was calculated using Eq.7. The amount of carbon deposited on the catalyst surface, calculated by TPO experiments was also taken into account. (7) C a r b o n t o t a l = [ C O ] + [ C O 2 ] + C a c c u m u l a t e d In all cases examined, the carbon balance is satisfactory, with deviation between 1.5 and 7.5%. 3.3 Effect of Pd loading on the adsorption/desorption characteristics of CO over Pd/CeO2 catalysts 3.3.1 Transient-MS results The effect of Pd loading on the adsorption/desorption characteristics of CO was investigated over 0, 0.25, 0.5 and 1.0% Pd/CeO2 catalysts. The transient-MS responses obtained at 70 °C upon switching from He to 0.004%CO + 0.01%Ar (in He) are presented in Figs. 4 A-D for the four samples investigated. In the case of pure CeO2 the response of CO appears immediately after the switch and reaches a steady state within less than 2 min-on-stream (not shown clearly due to the large scale of X-axis). The time response of CO increases by about 1 h with increasing Pd loading from 0.0 to 1.0 wt. %, indicating that CO adsorption is enhanced with increasing metal content, as would be expected. Traces of CO2 also appear which seem not to be dependent on Pd loading. Results of Fig. 4 indicate that the total amount of CO adsorbed on the catalyst surface increases with increasing the exposed Pd surface. This is supported by the results of Table 3 , where it can be seen that the amount of CO adsorbed progressively increases from 4.2 to 82.7 μmol g−1 with increasing Pd loading from 0 to 1 wt.%, respectively. Regarding the surface coverage of adsorbed CO, it was estimated to be equal to 8.8, 6.0 and 1.4 for the catalysts loaded with 0.25%, 0.5% and 1.0%Pd, respectively. This provides evidence that, in all cases, part of CO is adsorbed on the surface of CeO2 support, the amount of which increases as the Pd loading decreases. This can be explained taking into account that the peripheral area between Pd particles and CeO2 support is higher for catalysts of low Pd content thus, resulting in higher Pd dispersions and exposed CeO2 surface, where CO can be adsorbed. This agrees well with previous studies over Pt/Al2O3 [19], Ru/Al2O3 [37], Ru/TiO2 [37], Pt/CexZr1–xO2 [38] and Pt/CeO2 [39] catalysts, where it was demonstrated that the length of the perimeter of metal-support interface increases with decreasing metal loading. TPD patterns obtained following interaction of the pre-oxidized 0, 0.25, 0.5 and 1 wt.% Pd/CeO2 catalysts with 0.004%CO-0.01%Ar (in He) mixture at 70 °C are shown in Figs. 4E-H. In the case of pure CeO2 (Fig. 4E), it is observed that an amount of adsorbed CO is desorbed molecularly, whereas the rest interacts with CeO2 surface yielding CO2 and H2. Possible reactions, which have been proposed to be catalyzed by CeO2, include the WGS [40,41] and Boudouard [42,43] reactions, as well as CO oxidation by reactive ceria lattice oxygen [41,42], decomposition of carbonate species [41] and reduction of CeO2 surface (at high temperatures) [44]. As will be shown below, CO adsorption on pure CeO2 results in the formation of carbonate species [40,41], which are progressively desorbed with increasing temperature, releasing CO2 in the gas phase. Evolution of H2 during TPD indicates that the WGS reaction is operable on pure CeO2, whereas CO2 production during TPO experiment (Fig. 5 ), conducted immediately after TPD, confirms the occurrence of Boudouard reaction. In the case of CeO2 supported Pd catalysts (Fig. 4F–H), the obtained CO, CO2 and H2 profiles as a function of temperature are qualitatively similar with those presented in Figs. 2E–H, indicating that the same reactions are operable upon interaction of CO with Pd/CeO2 catalysts of variable Pd loading. The main difference observed between the investigated catalysts is related to the total amount of desorbed CO, CO2 and H2, which is significantly higher compared to that desorbed from pure CeO2 and increases progressively with increasing Pd loading (Table 3) in accordance with the results discussed above (Figs. 4A–D). It should be noted however, that among possible surface reactions taking place during CO-TPD, CO2 production via decomposition of carbonate species associated with CeO2 is expected to be retarded with increasing Pd content due to the lower exposed surface of CeO2 support. This is also the case for oxygen spillover phenomenon from CeO2 to Pd surface, followed by oxidation of CO toward CO2, which has been found to be suppressed with increasing Pd particles [35]. Therefore, two opposing tendencies seem to exist with increasing Pd loading; (a) Palladium surface increases leading to larger amount of CO adsorbed, whereas (b) metal-support interface decreases resulting in lower amount of CO adsorbed on CeO2. Comparison of the relative intensities of the detected desorption peaks shows that the LT CO2 peak is higher than the MT peak only in the case of 0.5%Pd/CeO2 catalyst. This implies that one of the surface reactions which are responsible for evolution of CO2 at low temperatures is favored for the latter catalyst. Based on the peaks assignment discussed above, either reduction of PdOx species by CO (Eq. 2) and/or the Boudouard reaction (Eq. 3) are enhanced compared to the RWGS (Eq. 4), the decomposition of carbonate species (Eq. 5) or oxidation of CO adsorbed on Pd by oxygen migrated from CeO2 to Pd surface. Regarding the Boudouard reaction, results of TPO experiments (Fig. 5, Table 3) conducted immediately after completion of CO-TPD experiments showed that the amount of surface carbon produced during CO-TPD decreases with increasing Pd loading. This provides evidence that CO dissociation into CO2 and carbon is suppressed with increasing Pd particle size and agrees well with previous studies over Pd/Al2O3 [20] and Pd/SiO2 [21,45] catalysts. Although, no clear evidence is provided from the results of the present study related to the effect of Pd loading on the rate of the reduction of PdO x species by CO, it can be assumed that the population of the latter species is higher over 0.5%Pd catalyst leading to evolution of higher amount of CO2 at low temperatures during CO-TPD. 3.3.2 In situ FTIR spectra The interaction of CO with the catalyst surface was also investigated employing in situ FTIR spectroscopy experiments. In Fig. 6 A are shown transient DRIFT spectra obtained over pure CeO2 support, following exposure to 0.004%CO (in He) at 70 °C. It is observed that increasing time of exposure up to 60 min results in the progressive development of several bands located below 1700 cm−1, which are due to adsorbed species associated with the support. In particular, the bands detected at 1130 and 1210 cm−1 have been previously assigned to bridge carbonate species [46–48], the bands at 1436, 1343 and 1050 cm−1 are due to unidentate carbonate species [48–50], whereas those located at 1600 and 1300 cm−1 can been attributed to bidentate carbonates [47,48,51]. Regarding the band detected at 1560 cm−1, it has been reported that it is due to carboxylate species [47,48,51]. It should be noted, however, that the first step of CO interaction with the surface oxygen ions of a metal oxide results in the formation of carbonite CO2 2- anions, which may then be decomposed into surface carbonate species [52–55]. In the case of CeO2, different types of carbonites may be formed giving rise to the development of various IR bands located below 1700 cm−1 [52]. Although the distinction of carbonite and carbonate species cannot be accurately identified here, it is possible that the bands mentioned above contain contribution from both types of surface species. Moreover, formate species produced via interaction of CO with the hydroxyl groups of CeO2 may also contribute to the bands located at ca. 1560 and 1343 cm−1 [48,49,51,56–58]. Apart from the formate/carbonate bands, interaction of CO with CeO2 at 70 °C results in the progressive development of two negative bands located at 3716 and 3653 cm−1 (Fig. 6A), which characterize OH stretching modes of two types of different surface hydroxyl groups. These bands develop in parallel with peaks located at ca 1560 and 1343 cm−1, which, as discussed above, contain contributions from surface formate species associated with the support. Qualitatively similar results have been reported for CeO2 [40,41,51], Pd/CeO2 [28] and Pt/CeO2 [48] catalysts. It is therefore reasonable to suggest that the hydroxyl groups originally present on the CeO2 surface interact with incoming CO to yield formates, the population of which progressively increases with time. Prolonged exposure to CO, up to 210 min, does not result in any significant change in the spectra obtained. DRIFT spectra obtained from CeO2 support following interaction with a flowing 0.004%CO/He mixture at 70 °C for 210 min at 25 °C and subsequent stepwise heating up to 450 °C under He flow are shown in Fig. 7 A. It is observed that the spectrum recorded at 25 °C (trace a) is characterized by bands located at 1560, 1440, 1340, 1300, 1212, 1134 and 1030 cm−1, which, as discussed above, are due to formate-, carbonite- or carbonate-like species associated with the support, and by negative bands at 3716 and 3653 cm−1 due to losses of ν(OH) intensity of free hydroxyl groups of CeO2. Increasing temperature up to 200 °C results in an increase of the relative intensity of bands at 1340 and 1440 cm−1 (which shifts to 1475 cm−1 most possibly due to the observed increase of the band intensity) at the expense of band at 1303 cm−1. Moreover, a new band located at 1380 cm−1 also [58] appears, which has been previously assigned to unidentate carbonate species [46]. Based on the bands assignment discussed above, it can be suggested that bidentate carbonates are progressively converted to unidentate carbonates during heating of catalyst under He flow. At temperatures higher than 200 °C, the intensities of all bands start to decrease and almost disappear above 400 °C (traces i–j). This behavior is probably due to decomposition of carbonates toward CO2 in agreement with results reported by Wu et al. [41]. In Fig. 6B are shown transient DRIFT spectra obtained over 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalyst, following exposure to 0.004%CO (in He) at 70 °C. It is observed that interaction of the preoxidized catalyst with 0.004%CO/He mixture results in the progressive development of bands below 1700 cm−1 (trace a) which, are due to bidentate carbonates (bands at ca. 1627 and 1320 cm−1), unidentate carbonates (bands at ca. 1445, 1356 and 1054 cm−1) and carboxylate species (bands at ca. 1536 and 1093 cm−1) associated with the support. Formation of formate species may also contribute to the development of peaks at 1356 and 1536 cm−1. This is enhanced by the detection of bands attributable to consumption of OH groups (3720 and 3646 cm−1) originally present on the CeO2 surface, which as mentioned above interact with CO yielding formates. The frequency and relative intensity of all bands are more or less similar with those detected on the surface of pure CeO2, indicating that the same surface species are formed during interaction of CO with both CeO2 support and 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalyst. Interestingly, no bands in the ν(CO) region are observed. This indicates that either CO does not adsorb on the surface of Pd or, most possibly, the low concentration of CO (0.004%) used in the present study does not enable the detection of adsorbed carbonyl species on Pd even if they have been formed. Purging with He for 10 min and subsequent heating under He flow (Fig.7B) from 25 to 450 °C results in the progressive desorption of adsorbed surface species following a similar behavior with that discussed above over pure CeO2 (Fig. 7A). The relative population of unidentate carbonates seems to increase at the expense of bidentate carbonate species in accordance with the results of Fig. 7A, whereas most of the surface species are desorbed from the catalyst surface at lower temperatures (> 300 °C) in the presence of 0.25 wt.%Pd. Increase of Pd loading to 1 wt.% gives rise to the development of a new weak band located at ca. 2155 cm−1 (Fig. 6C), which can be assigned to linear CO adsorbed on Pd2+ in agreement with previous studies over Pd/CeO2 [23,59], Pd/zeolite Y [60], Pd/Al2O3 [61,62] and Pd/CeO2-TiO2 [29] catalysts. Interaction of CO with 1%Pd/CeO2 also results in the appearance of bands attributable to consumption of OH groups (3725 and 3640 cm-1) of CeO2 support and the formation of formate/carbonate species on CeO2 surface as indicated by the progressive development of bands at wavenumbers lower than 1700 cm-1. In particular, bands due to bidentate carbonates (1620 cm-1), carboxylates (1532 cm-1), unidentate carbonates (1400–1490, 1340 and 1040 cm-1) and/or formates (1340 and 1532 cm-1) can be discerned upon prolonged exposure (up to 210 min) of the catalyst to 0.004%CO/He mixture. Heating of the catalyst under He flow (Fig. 7C) results in a progressive decrease of the intensity of CO-Pd2+ band, which disappears above 100 °C. The bands corresponding to carbonates species are thermally more stable and temperatures higher than 200 °C are required in order to be desorbed from the catalyst surface. Comparison of the spectra obtained in He flow over CeO2, 0.25%Pd/CeO2 and 1%Pd/CeO2 shows the following differences: (a) The relative population of formate/carbonate species associated with CeO2 support decreases with increasing Pd content, most probably due to a decrease of the exposed CeO2 surface for catalysts with higher Pd loading. This is in accordance with previous studies over Pd/Al2O3 [63] and Ru/TiO2 [37] catalysts and agrees well with the estimated values of CO surface coverage, discussed above, which tend closer to 1 as Pd loading increases. (b) the desorption of the latter species takes place at lower temperatures as the Pd loading increases from 0 to 1 wt.% implying that the reaction driving formate/carbonate decomposition is enhanced; (c) The detection of carbonyl species adsorbed on Pd surface (CO-Pd2+) was only observed for the catalyst loaded with 1 wt.% Pd. This may imply that either CO is mainly adsorbed on CeO2 support or that surface reactions occurred with the participation of Pd-bonded carbonyls leading to evolution of CO and CO2 in the gas phase occurs rapidly and therefore, the detection of the corresponding bands is not feasible. It should be noted, however, that if CO could only adsorbed on the CeO2 surface, the total amount of CO adsorbed on pure CeO2 should has been higher compared to Pd/CeO2 catalysts and should decreased progressively with increasing the exposed Pd surface, whereas the opposite was observed (Table 3). Moreover, the hypothesis of the rapid conversion of adsorbed Pd carbonyls is also questionable, since even if that was the case, the adsorbed CO species on Pd surface should be discerned during the period of (210 min) catalyst interaction with the 0.004%CO/He mixture. Another possible explanation is, as discussed above, related to the extremely low concentration of CO (0.004%) used in the present study in combination with the low signal-to-noise ratio in the ν(CO) region for the investigated catalysts, which may prevent the detection of adsorbed carbonyl species with FTIR instrument. The low concentration of CO in the gas stream may also affect the partial pressure of gaseous CO in equilibrium with adsorbed CO, contributing to the lack of measurable IR signal. Thus, we believe that adsorbed Pd carbonyl species are formed on the catalyst surface and their population increases with increasing Pd content. Based on the above, it can be proposed that, during interaction of 0.004%CO/He mixture with Pd/CeO2 catalysts, CO is adsorbed on the surface of both Pd and CeO2 support, resulting in the formation of CO-Pd2+ and formate/carbonate species, respectively. These species participate in surface reactions upon heating of the catalyst under He flow. In particular, CO adsorbed on Pd surface can reduce PdO x species, can migrate to CeO2 surface, can be dissociated and/or interacted with hydroxyl groups of the CeO2 support, leading, in all cases, to evolution of CO2 in the gas phase. Part of CO adsorbed on CeO2 surface can be re-diffused on the surface of Pd via reverse spillover, where it is either involved in the above reactions or it is desorbed in the gas phase. The rest part of the adsorbed CO on CeO2 surface, in the form of carbonate species, is decomposed producing CO2. Carbonates decomposition seems to be favored with increasing Pd loading as evidenced by the increased amount of CO2 estimated with CO-TPD experiments (Fig. 4D-F) and the disappearance of carbonate bands at lower temperatures from the DRIFT spectra (Fig. 7). This may be related to the suppression of the reverse spillover of CO, which has been reported to occur with increasing Pd particle size [27], implying that CO adsorbed on CeO2 surface prefers to be converted to CO2 via carbonate decomposition rather than to be diffused on Pd surface. As discussed above, an alternatively pathway for the formation of carbonate species, involves interaction of CO-Pd2+ species with the lattice oxygen of interfacial CeO2 [29]. This interaction may be attenuated with increasing Pd loading or particle size, due to a decrease of the metal/support interface and may be responsible for the observed decrease of the population of carbonate species with increasing Pd content. However, if the formation of carbonate species takes place according to this scheme, it should be operable only in the presence of metal. Although this scheme cannot be excluded over Pd/CeO2 catalysts, DRIFT spectra obtained from pure CeO2 are characterized by similar bands (Figs. 6A and 7 A), clearly indicating that this pathway is not the only one yielding carbonates. In any case, results of the present study demonstrate that the conversion of traces of CO to CO2 over Pd/CeO2 catalysts is feasible and occurs in a bifunctional manner, with the participation of both the dispersed metallic phase and the support. 3.4 Adsorption/desorption characteristics of CO over 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalyst under reformate feed composition The reformate gas produced in fuel reformers, followed by treatment in water-gas shift (WGS) and CO methanation (or oxidation) reactors, contains considerable amounts of steam, H2 and CO2, which may influence CO adsorption on the catalyst surface. Thus, the adsorption/desorption characteristics of CO were investigated at 40 °C over 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalyst in the presence of H2, CO2 and H2O in the gas stream. In Fig. 8 are shown transient responses of gas phase CO, CO2, H2O and H2, obtained from the preoxidized 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalyst, following two successive isothermal cycles of exposure to 0.0038%CO + 0.044%Ar+0.29%CO2+6.8%H2+3.1% H2O (in He) mixture for 50 min (Fig. 8A–D) and subsequent oxidation in 20%O2/He flow at (T ad) 40 °C for 50 min (Fig. 8E-H). It is observed that, during the 1st cycle of exposure to the reformate gas stream, the response of CO starts to increase after 20 min on stream, reaching steady state at about 50 min (Fig. 8A). The responses of CO2 (Fig. 8B) and H2O (Fig. 8C) start to increase at shorter times (< 5 min), but times similar to those of CO response are required in order to reach steady state. Regarding H2 response, Fig. 8D shows that it appears immediately after the switch and reaches a steady state within 45–50 minutes-on-stream. During the 1st cycle of the subsequent catalyst oxidation no CO was desorbed (Fig. 8E), whereas evolution of CO2 (Fig. 8F), H2O (Fig. 8G) and H2 (Fig. 8H) was observed, which is completed during 30 min of catalyst exposure to 20%O2/He. The total amounts of CO, CO2, H2O and H2 adsorbed on the surface of 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalyst were estimated from Figs. 8A-D, by subtracting the area below the corresponding response curve from that of Ar and were found to be equal to 10, 227, 4000 and 5013 μmol g−1, respectively (Table 4 ). The total amounts of CO, CO2, H2O and H2 desorbed form the catalyst surface during oxidation process were calculated from the area below the corresponding curves (Figs. 8E-H), and were found to be equal to 0, 213, 3753 and 4300 μmol g-1, respectively. Results of Table 4 indicate that either the adsorbed CO is not able to be desorbed from the catalyst surface during catalyst interaction with 20%O2/He mixture or it is totally oxidized toward CO2. This may be related to possible variations of the Pd/PdO x surface following the 1st cycle. Regarding CO2, H2O and H2, the amounts estimated during oxidation are slightly lower than those calculated during catalyst interaction with the reformate mixture, indicating that a small part of both gases are unable to be desorbed during oxidation at 40 °C. Interestingly, evolution of H2 during oxidation process initiates at longer times compared to H2O desorption, providing evidence that even if adsorbed H2 is oxidized toward H2O, this occurs to a small extend (Figs. 8G, H). Results obtained after completion of the 2nd cycle of catalyst exposure to the reformate mixture followed by oxidation at 40 °C shows that the response of CO in the gas phase appears at shorter times (ca. 15 min) compared to the 1st cycle and reaches immediately steady state (Fig. 8A). An amount of 5.3 μmol g−1 of CO was estimated to be adsorbed, implying that half of the initial adsorbed CO amount was oxidized during the 1st oxidation cycle, whereas the rest remains adsorbed on the surface of 0.25%Pd/CeO2. The CO2 and H2 responses appear at slightly shorter times compared to that of the 1st cycle (Fig. 8B and D) and thus, resulting in lower amounts of CO2 (193 μmol g−1) and H2 (4600 μmol g−1) adsorbed. The opposite is observed for the response of H2O (Fig. 8C), the adsorbed amount of which was found to be slightly higher (4200 μmol g−1) than that estimated during the 1st cycle (Table 4). Results indicate that a small part of CO2 remains adsorbed on the catalyst surface after completion of the 1st cycle and therefore, the number of available sites for CO2 adsorption decreases, resulting in a decrease of the total amount of CO2 adsorbed. Moreover, it is generally accepted that both CO2 and H2O are mainly adsorbed on the surface of the support. Thus, it is possible that the observed variations between adsorbed CO2 and H2O amounts are related to competitive adsorption of these compounds to the same sites on the catalyst surface. As discussed above, CO can be adsorbed both on Pd and CeO2 surface. This is also the case for H2 adsorption, which is well known to be diffused (spillover) from the metal surface to the support over CeO2 supported catalysts. However, no accurate comparison can be made between adsorption of CO and H2, due to the significantly higher concentration of H2 (6.8%) used in these experiments compared to that of CO (0.0038%). Results obtained during the 2nd cycle of catalyst oxidation are qualitatively similar with those obtained during the 1st cycle (Fig. 8E-H); no CO was detected in the gas phase, whereas the amounts of CO2, H2O and H2 desorbed are lower compared to those estimated to be adsorbed (Table 4). The main difference observed is that the desorption peak of both H2O and H2 appears at shorter times during the 2nd cycle (Fig. 8G,H). This may be due to weaker adsorption of these compounds during the 2nd cycle, which is possibly related to variations of the Pd/PdO x surface following the 1st cycle, thus facilitating their desorption in the gas phase. Comparison between the results obtained during interaction of the 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalyst with 0.004%CO/He mixture (Fig. 2A) and 0.0038%CO + 0.044%Ar+0.29%CO2+6.8%H2+3.1%H2O/He mixture (Fig. 8A) at 40 °C shows that the CO adsorption is hindered in the presence of CO2, H2 and H2O in the gas stream, most possibly due to competitive adsorption on the same active sites. The TPD patterns obtained in He flow following the two successive isothermal cycles are presented in Fig. 9 . It is observed that only traces of preadsorbed CO (0.15 μmol g−1) desorbs molecularly from 0.25%Pd/CeO2. The rest amount of adsorbed CO participates in surface reactions upon heating under He flow yielding CO2 in the gas phase. The CO2 profile is characterized by a low temperature (LT) peak at ca 130 °C, which is accompanied by a shoulder at ca 165 °C and a weak medium temperature (MT) peak located at ca 340 °C. Based on the above discussion, the LT peaks can be attributed to the Boudouard reaction as well as the reduction of partially oxidized palladium, which may be formed during oxidation process. The MT peak is most possibly due to the WGS reaction and/or decomposition of carbonate species. Water desorbs from 0.25%Pd/CeO2 in the temperature range of 100–450 °C, exhibiting a maximum located at ca 190 °C, which is accompanied by a shoulder at 340 °C. Hydrogen profile is characterized by a broad feature between 100 and 350 °C. The total amounts of CO2, H2O and H2 desorbed during TPD was estimated to be 30, 300 and 73 μmol g−1, respectively (Table 4). The overall carbon balance was calculated for the two successive isothermal cycles of exposure to reformate and oxidation mixture followed by the TPD experiment, and was found to be satisfactory, with a deviation of <1%. Results of the present study demonstrate that elimination of CO at the exit of the CO methanation (or oxidation) reactor is feasible via (at least two) successive cycles of CO adsorption and oxidation at low temperatures over 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalyst. The efficiency of the process can be enhanced with increasing metal loading and/or with increasing the oxidation temperature, in order to remove the remaining adsorption species from the catalyst surface, recovering the active centers for CO adsorption and oxidation toward CO2. It should be noted however that oxidation temperature should be kept in low levels so as H2 oxidation to be prevented. The investigation of the effect of operating conditions on the efficiency of the proposed process will be the subject of our forthcoming publications. 4 Conclusions Carbon monoxide removal from reformed streams is currently the biggest barrier to connect H2-rich streams to commercially available PEM fuel cell devices. In the present study, an alternative approach for the reduction of CO residual is proposed, which involves subjection of Pd/CeO2 catalyst to successive cycles of interaction with the reformate mixture followed by oxidation at low temperatures, resulting in a CO-free hydrogen stream able to be fed to fuel cells for electricity production. Results showed that CO can be adsorbed on the catalyst surface with the participation of both the metallic phase and the support in a manner which depends strongly on the adsorption temperature and Pd loading employed, as well as on the presence of H2, CO2 and H2O in the gas stream, which competes with CO for the same adsorption sites. Although the latter compounds restrict CO adsorption on the catalyst surface, results of the present study demonstrated that elimination of CO employing the proposed technology is feasible with the use of 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Reformate gas mixtures introduced into PEM fuel cells may contain traces of CO which can irreversibly poison electrocatalysts. A means to eliminate such traces of CO from reformate mixtures via reactive adsorption onto solid catalysts is described. The reactive adsorption/desorption characteristics of CO were investigated over Pd/CeO2 catalysts with respect of Pd loading and adsorption temperature employing in situ FTIR and transient MS techniques. Results showed that CO adsorption is enhanced with increasing Pd content or decreasing adsorption temperature. Production of CO2 during CO-TPD occurs in a bifuntional manner with the participation of both the metallic phase and the support. Although the adsorption of CO is limited upon interaction of 0.25%Pd/CeO2 catalyst with a reformate mixture, results demonstrate that elimination of residual CO, present in the exit of methanation (or oxidation) reactor, is feasible via successive cycles of CO adsorption and oxidation at 40 °C.
coredata.dc:title: Reactive adsorption of CO from low CO concentrations streams on the surface of Pd/CeO2 catalysts
